newsitem.title: JAPAN: TOCOM precious metals end lower as yen firms.
newsitem.headline: TOCOM precious metals end lower as yen firms.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo precious metals futures ended lower across the board on Monday, hit by a sharp fall in the New York market on Friday and a stronger yen against the dollar today, traders said.
All silver futures were glued to their daily limit-lows throughout the day, pressured by weak spot silver prices.
Daily price fluctuations in silver futures are limited to six yen per 10 grams.
Benchmark April silver closed six yen weaker at 178.5 yen.
Gold futures ranged from 24 yen to 28 yen per gram weaker. Most-active benchmark April ended 26 yen down at 1,275 yen.
Traders tended to be bearish on gold futures, as sentiment in bullion was dented by news last week that Germany planned to revalue its gold reserves.
Spot gold was quoted at $343.25/75 per ounce at 0733 GMT, against $343.80/344.30 in New York on Friday.
Platinum futures were hit by animated selling pressure, while losses in palladium futures were limited because spot market tightness has shown little sign of easing, traders said.
"Market players were building fresh shorts in platinum futures in anticipation that Russia may resume platinum group metals (PGM) exports," one trader said.

However, traders said that there had been little progress in Japan-Russia PGM export contract talks, since last week when the Russian platinum group metal agency (Almazjuvelirexport) informed Japanese clients that PGM exports would resume soon.

Platinum futures may head lower in an attempt to correct the recent rally, while a large overhang of short positions in TOCOM palladium futures may limit palladium's losses even if Russia resumes exports, the trader said.
Benchmark April palladium ended eight yen per gram weaker at 592 yen. Benchmark April platinum stood 33 yen per gram lower at 1,398 yen. -- Tokyo Commodity Desk
